title-group.subtitle: Prescribers’ Need for and Access to Drug Information Resources in Ethiopia

article-meta.aff: 1Clinical Pharmacy Unit, Pharmacy Department, College of Public Health and Medical Science, Jimma University, Jimma, Ethiopia
2Pharmaceutics Unit, Department of Pharmacy, College of Public Health and Medical Science, Jimma University, Jimma, Ethiopia
3School of Public Health, University of Washington, Seattle WA, USA
4Pharmaceutical Analysis Unit, Department of Pharmacy, College of Public Health and Medical Science, Jimma University, Jimma, Ethiopia

author-notes.corresp: Nasir Tajure Wabe, MSc, Clinical Pharmacy Unit, Department of Pharmacy, College of Public Health and Medical Science, Jimma University, P.O. Box 251 1480, Jimma, Ethiopia. Email: nasir.wabe@ju.edu.et

abstract.p: Rational and cost-effective prescription of drugs requires up-to-date and readily accessible drug information (DI). Availability of and access to DI resources are major factors that affect quality of prescription. The aim of the study was to assess prescribers’ DI needs and access to DI resources in Ethiopia. A facility-based, cross-sectional, quantitative study was conducted from February to April 2011 in 4 selected public health facilities in southwest Ethiopia. Data on areas of DI needs, access to DI resources, and attitudes of prescribers toward DI services were collected using a structured, self-administered questionnaire. The study population consisted of 410 of 447 initially contacted prescribers. The majority of the prescribers (93.4%) explained their needs for DI services. About 32.4% of the participants do not frequently refer to DI resources mainly due to the difficulty of acquiring the required information promptly and/or because they do not have access to DI resources. Compared with participants from a health center, participants from specialized referral, zonal, and district hospitals were found to be 6 (adjusted odds ratio [AOR], 5.81; 95% confidence interval [CI], 2.77-12.20), 5 (AOR, 4.77; 95% CI, 2.43-9.38), and 4 (AOR, 4.00; 95% CI, 1.50-10.66) times more likely to consult DI resources, respectively. Lack of access to DI resources and difficulty in acquiring the required information on time were the main reasons that prescribers gave for not frequently referring to DI resources. DI services should be established and expanded in health facilities.

body.p: Drug information (DI) services include the activities of specially trained individuals to provide unbiased, up-to-date, evidence-based information on drugs in response to patient-oriented problems submitted by various members of the health care team. 1 In developing countries, many health care workers have little or no access to basic and practical information. Indeed, many rely on observing other practitioners, obtaining advice from colleagues, and building experience empirically through their own treatment successes and failures. In the last decade, some important steps have been made toward meeting the information needs of the upper levels of health professions (research and tertiary care), but remarkably little progress has been achieved in meeting the information needs of primary and district health care providers in the developing world. 2

The explosive growth of medical knowledge necessitates that physicians seek knowledge from diverse information sources. 3 To understand and improve the services that provide access to relevant professional information, several studies 4–6 have investigated health care providers’ information needs and information-seeking behavior. These studies have shown that there are identifiable classes of information needs and patterns of information-seeking behaviors among health care practitioners.

The biggest barrier to initiating DI services is a lack of awareness of the necessity for these services. There is also resistance from prescribers who believe they have sufficient information and do not make mistakes, despite overwhelming evidence of common errors in medication and poor choice of drugs based on incomplete and biased information. 4

Gaps in knowledge related to drug prescribing are among the most common causes of serious medication errors. Internet searching presents difficulties for physicians, given the extensive amount of information to scan and lack of specificity of available information. 7 In an era of unparalleled, explicit knowledge about the causes and effective treatments of disease and outstanding electronic resources to access such knowledge, physicians continue to have difficulty in answering clinical questions that arise when caring for patients, largely because of lack of time and insufficient training in the use of electronic databases. 8
,
9

Given the enormous number of drug products available worldwide and the complexity of the current drug literature, selection and use of appropriate drugs are challenging and difficult. This motivates health care practitioners and providers to seek new types of services from pharmacists in the field of rational therapeutics. 10

Providing good DI is potentially one of the most cost-effective interventions that agencies can use. Often, agencies spend considerable amounts of money to supply medicines without providing information on how to use the medicines. Information has a much more important function in the use medicines compared with most other goods. Without appropriate information, medicines could produce, at best, an acceptable outcome and, at worst, a disastrous outcome in terms of morbidity or mortality. Therefore, providing appropriate information for the rational use of medicines is a key component to achieving their full potential. Thus, the aim of the study was to assess DI needs of prescribers in selected public health facilities in southwest Ethiopia.

sec.title: Study Setting
sec.p: The study was conducted in 4 public health facilities in southwest Ethiopia. The study included prescribers from 1 health center (Jimma Town Health Center), 1 district hospital (Limu Genet Hospital), 1 zonal hospital (Mettu Karl Hospital), and 1 specialized referral hospital (Jimma University Specialized Hospital). Jimma University Specialized Hospital is located in Jimma town and is the only teaching and referral hospital in the southwestern part of Ethiopia. It provides specialized health services through its 9 medical and other clinical and diagnostic departments for approximately 9,000 inpatients and 80,000 outpatients each year and has a bed capacity of 450. Jimma Town Health Center, located at the center of Jimma town, aims to serve a total of 25,000 people from the town. Limu Genet Hospital is also located in Limu Genet town in Jimma zone. It provides comprehensive health services to 500,000 people from the surrounding area and has a bed capacity of 150. Mettu Karl Hospital is located in Mettu town in Ilu Abba Bora Zone in southwest Ethiopia. It is a zonal hospital that provides comprehensive health services to over 1,000,000 people and has a bed capacity of 250.

sec.title: Study Design
sec.p: This facility-based, cross-sectional study was conducted from February to April 2011. Four health facilities were selected from all available health facilities in southwest Ethiopia as follows: The specialized referral hospital was selected because this is the only specialized hospital in the area; for the zonal and regional hospitals, 1 hospital was selected from each category using simple random sampling technique (lottery method), and the health center was selected purposefully. The gross number of prescribers in the selected health facilities was 447. Considering that the study population is small in number when divided among these 4 health facilities, we enrolled all prescribers available during the study period.

sec.title: Data Collection and Management
sec.p: A structured, self-administered questionnaire was used for data collection. Before the data collection process began, the questionnaires were pretested on 45 prescribers in other health facilities. Registered pharmacists were recruited from each facility for the purpose of data collection, and 1 day of training and orientation was given by the principal investigator. After consent was obtained from the participants, the questionnaire was given to individual prescribers. Their response was collected on the next day.

The need for DI services was measured on a Likert scale (1 = not important, 2 = important, 3 = essential). The results were summed to produce a score that ranges from 3 to 9. Based on the mean score, the need for DI service was dichotomized as “not important” when the score was less than the mean value and “important” when the score was greater than or equal to the mean value. The importance of areas of DI was measured by 18 items on a 3-point scale (1 = not important, 2 = important, 3 = very important). These items were summed to produce scores that ranged from 18 to 54. Based on the mean score, the importance of areas of DI was dichotomized as “not important” when the score was less than the mean value and “important” when the score was greater than or equal to the mean value. In the same manner, the difficulty of accessing information was measured by 18 items on a 3-point scale (1 = accessible, 2 = difficult to access, 3 = very difficult to access). These items were summed to produce a score that ranges from 18 to 54. Based on the mean score, information was dichotomized as “accessible” when the score was less than the mean value and “difficult to access” when the score was greater than or equal to the mean value.

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: The collected data were categorized, edited, cleaned, and analyzed using the Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS) for Windows version 16 (SPSS, Chicago, Illinois). Means, standard deviations (SDs), and 95% confidence intervals (95% CIs) were calculated, and a P value of less than .05 was considered to be statistically significant. Categorical data were analyzed using binary logistic analysis. A multivariate logistic regression was performed to analyze the relationship between accessibility to various DI resources and practice settings. The results are presented in tables, graphs, and percentages.

sec.title: Ethics
sec.p: This study was approved by the Jimma University ethics committee. A letter of approval and cooperation was also obtained from Jimma Zonal Health Bureaus. Participation in the study was entirely voluntarily, and written consent was taken before administering the questionnaires. Confidentiality of the information provided by the study participants was maintained throughout the study period.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Of the 447 questionnaires distributed, 410 were returned, for a response rate of 91.72%. Respondents were predominantly males: 320 (78%). Their age ranged from 20 to 65 years, with a median of 26 years. Their experience ranged from 6 months to 44 years, with a mean of 4 years. The majority of respondents were medical interns (34.38%), followed by nurses (21.7%). Others included residents (14.88%), dental interns (7.32%), specialists (6.83%), health officers (4.15%), general practitioners (3.18%), and others (7.56%).

Almost all of the respondents, 402 (98%), are aware that provision of DI is the professional responsibility of pharmacists. The remaining 8 respondents (2%) believe that DI should be provided by all health professionals as a team or obtained from reference books, that other health professionals should provide the service (because pharmacists are not communicative), or that the physician and pharmacist in collaboration should provide the service. The majority of the prescribers, 381 (92.9%), had requested information about drugs during their previous clinical practice.

Table 1 shows the prescribers’ accessibility to various DI resources in the study areas. The most accessible DI resource at the specialized referral hospital was textbooks, and the least accessible resource was newsletters. National guidelines were the most accessible DI resources at other health facilities.

caption.p: Prescribers’ accessibility to various drug information resources.

fn.p: All values are expressed as n (%).

sec.p: Compared with participants from the health center, participants from the specialized referral hospital were 16 times (adjusted odds ratio [AOR], 16.56; 95% CI, 6.98-39.30) more likely to have access to textbooks. Compared with participants from the health center, participants from the specialized referral hospital were 7 times more likely to have access to journal resources (AOR, 7.08) at 95% CI. However, this association was not maintained on multivariate analysis for the zonal hospital (Table 2).

caption.p: Association of accessibility to various drug information resources with practice settings, AOR (95% CI).

fn.p: AOR, adjusted odds ratio; CI, confidence interval.

sec.p: A total of 232 (79.2%) respondents from the specialized referral hospital, 21 (39.6%) from the regional hospital, 15 (35.7%) from the district hospital, and 9 (40.9%) from the health center frequently consulted DI resources. The results showed that 133 (32.4%) of the respondents didn’t frequently consult DI resources, mainly due to lack of time; other reasons included inability to obtain the required information promptly, difficulty in accessing DI resources, difficulty in determining reliable resources, and the belief that the available resources are outdated and the information is vast and difficult to filter. Multivariate analysis showed an association between practice setting and the pattern of consultation of DI resources. Accordingly, compared with participants from the health center, participants from the specialized referral (AOR, 5.81; 95% CI, 2.77-12.20), zonal (AOR, 4.77; 95% CI, 2.43-9.38), and district hospitals (AOR, 4.00; 95% CI, 1.50-10.66) were found to be 6, 5, and 4 times more likely, respectively, to frequently consult DI resources.

The top 3 areas of DI considered very important by the majority of the respondents were dosing in renal failure, use in pregnancy and lactation, and contraindications. The areas that need DI and the areas of DI that respondents considered very difficult to access are described in Figures 1 and 2.

caption.p: Areas of drug information rated by the respondents.
Accessibility to information on the specific areas of drug information.

sec.p: The majority of the respondents (75.4%) rated the importance of DI services as essential (Table 3). The usefulness of establishing DI services in health facilities was strongly supported by the majority of respondents (78.5%). Most of the participants said that they need DI most importantly while rounding patients (Table 4). Accordingly, compared with prescribers from the health center, prescribers from the specialized referral hospital were 32 times more likely to demand DI while rounding patients (AOR, 32.53; 95% CI, 11.07-95.55). Compared with prescribers from the health center, participants from the specialized referral (AOR, 8.02; 95% CI, 1.67-38.50) and district hospitals (AOR, 6.10; 95% CI, 1.56-23.87) were found to be 8 and 6 times more likely, respectively, to demand DI while treating critical cases in intensive care units, unlike prescribers from the zonal hospital (AOR, 0.09; 95% CI, 0.02-0.42), who were less likely to demand DI.

caption.p: Rating the importance of establishing drug information services in health facilities as need indicator.

fn.p: All values are expressed as n (%).

caption.p: Specific conditions in which prescribers need more drug information with practice settings.

fn.p: All values are expressed as n (%). ED, emergency department; ICU, intensive care unit.

sec.p: The most preferred channel for information exchange with DI centers in the selected public health facilities is personal contact. Fax is the least preferred channel in those facilities (Table 5). However, multivariate analysis showed an association only for e-mail with practice settings. Compared with participants from the health center, participants from the specialized referral hospital (AOR, 4.35; 95% CI, 1.11-17.07), zonal hospital (AOR, 3.48; 95% CI, 1.14-10.60), and district hospital (AOR, 3.52; 95% CI, 1.32-9.40) were, respectively, 4, 3, and 4 times more likely to prefer e-mail as a means for information exchange with the DI centers.

caption.p: Channels for exchange of drug information with drug information centers.

fn.p: All values are expressed as n (%).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The results of this study show that a majority of the prescribers (93.4%) demonstrated a need for DI services. This is comparable to findings from studies done in India (97%), 11 Estonia (88%), 12 and Uganda (80%). 13 This finding reflects the lack of proper DI services in public health facilities, which is experienced by almost all of the respondents; it might be the case that prescribers know that current available resources do not satisfy their DI needs and, therefore, hope that the public health center will be a better source for information, especially regarding patient-specific queries. The study showed no association between practice settings and need for DI; thus, the need for DI was established regardless of the level of health facility.

The purpose of establishing DI services in health facilities is to improve treatment outcomes and quality of care. Participants in the study also believe that establishing DI services in health facilities minimizes medication errors, improves prescription practices, and reduces cost of treatment. These could be considered as indicators of what prescribers expect from DI services.

Even though textbooks are good sources of basic DI, they do not provide the most advanced or latest information, given that standards of medicine may change during the time it takes to publish a book. In our study, about one-third of Internet users complained that the information available online is vast and difficult to filter. One study done in the US 14 indicated the continued lack of quality control for Internet documents and the lack of literature regarding potential harm from advice retrieved from the Internet. National guidelines usually provide limited information on drugs and may not provide patient-specific information. Drug package inserts and leaflets supplied by pharmaceutical companies mainly contain basic information on the product. The findings of a study done in India 11 indicated that 79% of clinicians felt that information provided by pharmaceutical companies is biased and inadequate. The results of the current study also showed a lack of access to DI resources such as newsletters, journals, and drug indexes that provide up-to-date and patient-specific information; this, in turn, may affect quality of prescription. The scarcities of these resources were significant at the zonal and district hospitals and the health center.

In the present study, a significant number of prescribers did not frequently consult DI resources, mainly because it was difficult to acquire information promptly and/or because they did not have access to DI resources. This investigation thus reveals that lack of access to DI resources in general and lack of DI resources that can be accessed quickly to meet the immediate needs of prescribers in particular are possible reasons why prescribers do not consult DI resources, especially in resource-limited settings. This finding is different from the findings of a study done in Uganda, 13 where lack of time was the major reason for not frequently consulting DI resources. The difference could be due to differences in working environments as well as availability of DI resources in health facilities. Moreover, multivariate analysis showed an association between practice settings and the pattern of consultation of DI resources: Prescribers from specialized referral, zonal, and district hospitals were more likely to consult DI resources compared with prescribers from the health center. This might be due to an increase in complexity of cases handled and relatively better accessibility to DI resources as the level of health facilities increases.

Dosing in renal failure, use in pregnancy and lactation, contraindications, adverse drug reactions, and availability and cost were the 5 top areas of DI considered as very important by two-third of the respondents. The study showed no association between practice settings and areas of DI. In another study, 12 availability and price of medicines, use in the elderly, drug interactions, and use during pregnancy and lactation were considered as important areas that need DI.

A majority of the prescribers indicated that they need more DI during patient rounding. Treating patients in the emergency department and treating critical cases in the intensive care unit were other situations in which prescribers indicated more need for DI. Furthermore, multivariate analysis showed an association between practice settings and specific conditions in which prescribers indicated more need for DI. Accordingly, prescribers from the specialized referral hospital are more likely to need DI during patient rounding and when treating critical cases in the intensive care unit compared with prescribers from the health center. This might be because patient rounding as a health care team is a day-to-day practice in the specialized referral teaching hospital and critical cases are usually referred to a specialized referral hospital. These results indicate that DI is urgently needed in some situations, and providers may require quickly accessible DI resources like personal digital assistants (PDAs) or palmtops that can be used to access DI at the point of patient care.

Personal contact was the most preferred channel for drug information exchange in these health facilities. This method of information exchange could be time-consuming and inconvenient in situations where information is urgently needed.

We believe that this study addresses an important issue regarding DI needs of prescribers in southwest Ethiopia. However, the findings of this study have some limitations and should be interpreted with care. As this was a cross-sectional study, it is susceptible to recall bias including the probability that the prescribers’ patterns of consultation of DI resources had been forgotten. It is assumed that the selected health facilities are representative of other centers in southwest Ethiopia. However, the pattern of DI needs of prescribers at specialized hospitals might be different from other health centers, given professional educational levels and other factors. Because the study was conducted only in the southwest area of the country, the findings may not be generalizable to the whole country.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: There is a high need for DI services from prescribers; lack of access to DI resources was identified as a problem that may affect prescribers’ clinical practice, especially at regional and district hospitals and at health centers. Lack of access to DI resources and difficulty in acquiring the required information promptly were the 2 major reasons that prescribers did not frequently consult DI resources. DI services should be established and/or expanded in health facilities; federal health officials and policy makers should give special attention to this issue, as the service is critical for efficient patient care and management.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors acknowledge the study health facilities, the data collectors, and the study participants.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The study was funded by Jimma University.
